posts.cooked:
Suddenly, without warning, today I cannot send (and presumably receive) messages anymore. The Signal app displays “This version of Signal has expired. Update now to send and receive messages.”

This is bad UX because:

  • there was no timely warning that this will happen
  • there is no explanation as to why this happens
  • it forces the user into alternative, insecure, communication channels in case updating the app is not feasable
  • considering I’m on v6.30.* and the current version is v6.40.*, there should be no backwards incompatibility, therefore I feel like I’m forced to jump through hoops for no valid reason. I’d argue that blocking the app isn’t reasonable even if there was a known security vulnerability in my version.

Suggestion for improvement:

  • never take control away from the user (if want that I’ll stick to Facebook Messenger)
  • warn the user (every 30 days?) that their app is behind with the updates
  • if the core app functionality (sending messages) is no longer compatible with the server, the user should be informed and asked to update

Somebody else having this issue: Wrong date settings on phone: "This version of Signal has expired"

Gippity is more well-spoken and has some additional note-worthy considerations regarding why this could be considered bad UX:

Summary
  1. Unexpected Disruption: Users generally expect continuity in their app usage. A sudden expiration of the app version can disrupt their communication unexpectedly, which can be particularly problematic in urgent or important situations.
  2. Forced Update: This approach forces users to update the app immediately to continue using it. Users may not always be in a position to update the app instantly due to various reasons like limited data availability, being in the middle of an important conversation, or using an older device that might not support the latest update.
  3. Lack of Prior Warning: A good UX design involves informing users well in advance about any significant changes that could impact their usage. If users are not warned about the impending expiration of their app version, they can be caught off guard.
  4. Potential Accessibility Issues: Some users might face challenges in updating apps due to reasons like lack of familiarity with the process, limited internet access, or restrictions due to device capabilities. Forcing an update without providing alternatives or assistance can exclude these users.
  5. Trust and Perception: This kind of abrupt change can affect the user’s trust in the app. Users might perceive the app as unreliable or feel that their needs are not being considered, which can lead to frustration or even abandonment of the app.
  6. Update Size and Data Constraints: If the update is large in size, it might be inconvenient for users with limited data plans or slow internet connections.

I agree that there should be a warning, but it is necessary to update app and keep it up to date to avoid vulnerabilities and feature confusion

I’ll try and unpack that:

  • it is necessary to update app and keep it up to date to avoid vulnerabilities
    For known and patched vulnerabilities yes, that is true. But the current process only works after 90 days, any user can run a vulnerable Signal app potentially for up to 89 days.

  • it is necessary to [keep the app updated] to avoid feature confusion
    Should be fine as long as you inform the user. If I remember correctly, Facebook and Whatsapp display a warning that “some features might not work correctly until you update”;
    I understand it’s convenient to not have to think about backwards compatibility, but I’d have to ask, what are you doing that you need to break BC every 90 days, in a nine year old app?
    I’m curious what happens for the first 90 days after a braking change is released, do the previous versions just crash? If not, then the incompatibility is handled somehow for the first 90 days, and maybe that interval should be extended if there’s no good reason for it being exactly 90 days.

Disliking app updates is a whole other topic (don’t tell me you never regretted updating an app).

But more importantly, are you able to update? -please see below.

Talya (she/her):

why is [app update] not feasible? if you’ve got the network to send and receive messages and the space to store them, what’s preventing you from updating?

Off the top of my head:

  • lack of free space - personally, I’ve often found myself not being able to update apps because that requires significant free space (more than 500MB), but most apps would continue to work. Receiving messages is not bound by the same free space requirement.
  • limited data availability - an unexpected 25 MB download might be a luxury you do not have (think prepaid SIM in a foreign country with crazy roaming prices and insufficient credit, no way to top up etc.) - e.g. Serbia €5 per 10MB
  • limited network speed - you’re in remote location with bad connectivity, you can barely squeeze out a message on 2G 10kbps connection, you’ll never finish downloading that 25MB update
  • time-sensitive communication - your in the middle of something, waiting for that important message, or need to send out a message quickly - of course you’re not going to update, it takes time to update, time you don’t have - you are forced to switch to some other potentially unsafe channel
  • sometimes Play Store update just doesn’t work - I know because I made this search many times: unable to update apps google play store at DuckDuckGo
  • other concrete examples here: Wrong date settings on phone: "This version of Signal has expired" - #7 by anon64272229

Hope I was able to bring more clarity to this issue.

The only thing I agree with is that it certainly would be helpful to have an advance notice that you should update your app. It could help out some people who aren’t getting automatic updates for some reason and aren’t aware, and also serve as a heads up for people who are intentionally avoiding updates.

Hello123:

IMO the right way™ to solve the “vulnerable old app” problem is for the Signal server to refuse to serve vulnerable clients OR warn the user to update. If we wrongly assume timely updates for all users, we actually leave some users exposed, potentially running a vulnerable version for 89 days.

They already have a built-in mechanism to remotely expire builds before the automatic 90 day limit, so the case of a serious vulnerability requiring immediate updates is already covered.

Hello123:

The backwards compatibility can be handled with some preparation or some workaround, like many other software projects do.

They do this as well. For features that will absolutely break things, they implement receive ability first and wait for the build to roll out for a certain amount of time before beginning to make send capability available. But this still requires that users actually update, which is where the automatic build expiration comes into play; otherwise you’d have people hanging out on super old versions causing problems (whether intentionally or not) for themselves and others.

Hello123:

For the new message editing feature, I can think of a maybe dumb solution - don’t allow editing when the other client doesn’t support it.

That requires additional overhead of advertising features to everyone you’re talking to so the client knows what it can do, and now everything has to have conditional logic and testing had to be done for all the possible combinations. That’s a major unnecessary increase in dev work for a very small team.

Hello123:

lack of free space - personally, I’ve often found myself not being able to update apps because that requires significant free space (more than 500MB)

The universal Signal APK is 85 MB (the download from the website that contains all the variants); device-specific versions from the Play Store are even less. If your phone doesn’t have enough space to update that, it’s not going to be functioning at all.

Hello123:

limited data availability - an unexpected 25 MB download might be a luxury you do not have

Luckily, you can go 90 days in normal conditions and you can plan when to update your app knowing that it will expire 90 days from when it was released. At most you have to download less than 85 MB four times in a year.

Hello123:
  • limited network speed - you’re in remote location with bad connectivity, you can barely squeeze out a message on 2G 10kbps connection, you’ll never finish downloading that 25MB update
  • time-sensitive communication - your in the middle of something, waiting for that important message, or need to send out a message quickly - of course you’re not going to update, it takes time to update, time you don’t have - you are forced to switch to some other potentially unsafe channel

All the more reason to keep the app regularly updated so you don’t end up in that situation. Again, in the worst case scenario you just have to make a plan to update once a quarter, maybe slightly more often if you are likely to end up in a situation where you might need more wiggle room.

Hello123:

sometimes Play Store update just doesn’t work

Luckily, you can download the APK in a situation like that.

Hello123:

other concrete examples here: Wrong date settings on phone: “This version of Signal has expired” - #7 by anon64272229

That’s definitely an unfortunate situation, but I’d argue it’s rare enough to not be a significant concern.

You know what they say about assumptions. Assumptions like:

  • how often the users open the app 80 days after the last update
  • how fast or affordable the users’ internet connection is 90 days after the last update
  • how much the users care about the latest shiny feature vs. autonomy and reliability
  • how willing your users are to jump through hoops to use the app vs. any competitor app, even as seldom as every 90 days
  • how “digitally apt” some users are (e.g. to be able to install apps by downloading APKs).

These seemingly minor UX details are especially relevant when compared to the competition. Any friction for the user (or his circle) vs. WhatsApp or FB Messenger etc. erodes the slim market slice that Signal has.
But then again, maybe it isn’t healthy right now for Signal’s growth to acquire or keep the types of users for which these considerations apply.
